TI RHEOLOGICAL PROPERTIES OF A HOMOGENEOUS THERMOTROPIC LIQUID-CRYSTALLINE
   POLYESTER - DYNAMIC VISCOELASTIC AND INTERRUPTED-FLOW MEASUREMENTS
SO MACROMOLECULES
LA English
DT Article
ID HELICAL POLYPEPTIDES; BANDED STRUCTURES; MAIN-CHAIN; POLYMERS; PHASE
AB Dynamic viscoelastic and shear stress properties at various shear rates with intermediate rest periods of varying length were measured for a thermotropic nematic liquid-crystalline polyester of homogeneous backbone structure, with a long flexible spacer.  Data obtained in the liquid-crystalline and isotropic states were found to independently superimpose when shifted along the omega axis.  In the low-frequency region of the liquid-crystalline state, data exhibit log G' and log G'' values less-than-or-equal-to 1 when plotted vs log omega.  Properties for the isotropic state correspond to other wide molecular weight distribution melts except here, and in the liquid-crystalline state, eta(gamma) < \eta*(omega)\.  While interrupted-flow (I-F) results in the isotropic state were similar to other isotropic materials, in the liquid-crystalline state at 145-degrees-C and similarly at 160-degrees-C, previously unsheared samples sheared at omega = 0.1 s-1 showed a stress maximum, accompanied by a transient negative first normal stress difference peak and later by a positive N1 peak.  At 160-degrees-C, omega = 0.5 s-1, a second stress overshoot appeared, as did another positive N1 peak.  When compared with optical micrographs of sheared samples, the first peak may be related to initial domain structure deformation, not reappearing in subsequent shear events after short rest periods.  The second stress overshoot that appears with higher shear rates appears to correspond to the complete breakdown of these domains, producing a birefringent yet featureless appearance.  Structure reappears with longer rest periods but differs from initial texture.  If sheared, this structure is capable of producing an initial stress overshoot.
C1 KYOTO UNIV,MED POLYMERS & BIOMAT RES CTR,SAKYO KU,KYOTO 606,JAPAN.
   IDEMITSU PETROCHEM CO LTD,PERFORMANCE POLYMERS RES LAB,CHIBA 2992,JAPAN.

PT J
AU FUJIWARA, K
AF FUJIWARA, K
TI POINT TO STRING TRANSFORMATION, OR FRAME-DEPENDENT NOTION OF LOCALITY -
   AN ATTEMPT TO FINITIZE FIELD-THEORIES INCLUDING GRAVITATION
SO GENERAL RELATIVITY AND GRAVITATION
LA English
DT Article
ID ENERGY
AB A novel approach has been made to the divergence problem in local field theories, in which the notion of "locality" is still retained but loses its absolute meaning, just like "simultaneity".  The basic idea is to introduce a pure-imaginary elementary length into 3-dimensional space, while keeping "time" structureless so as to retain the unitarity of the S-matrix.  Consequently, light becomes dispersive at sufficiently short wavelengths, and Lorentz transformation becomes a point-to-string transformation.  When reformulated to meet the new Lorentz invariance, all the local-field (in the above sense) theories in a flat space become finite, while retaining their conventional form.  This has been demonstrated by the derivation of finitized Coulomb potential and correct high-momentum behavior of quantum-electrodynamic coupling constant.  For diagrams including gravitons, evaluation of the superficial degrees of divergence shows that only a restricted number of 1- (and 2-) loop diagrams might be divergent, while those of more than 3 loops are definitely convergent, thus indicating possible renormalizability (or something better) of quantum gravity in Einstein's formalism of general relativity.  Since 4-dimensional simple supergravity removes 1- and 2-loop divergence, a combination of the theory and the present one might lead to a more interesting result.
RP FUJIWARA, K (reprint author), UNIV TOKYO,COLL ARTS & SCI,INST PHYS,MEGURO KU,TOKYO 153,JAPAN.
CR Bjorken J. D., 1965, RELATIVISTIC QUANTUM
   Bjorken J. D., 1965, RELATIVISTIC QUANTUM

TI LUMINESCENCE ASSOCIATED WITH SELF-TRAPPED EXCITONS IN LIBR
SO JOURNAL OF LUMINESCENCE
LA English

CT 1990 INTERNATIONAL CONF ON LUMINESCENCE ( ICL 90 )
CY JUL 16-20, 1990
CL LISBON, PORTUGAL
SP CALOUSTE GULBENKIAN FDN
ID ALKALI-HALIDE CRYSTALS
AB We have studied the luminescence properties of LiBr crystals cleaved at 6 K.  A drastic change of the luminescence spectrum on cleaving is found; the 5.4 eV band, which has been assigned to be the sigma band originating from the singlet self-trapped exciton (STE), disappears, and the 3.95 eV band, known to be the pi band from the triplet STE, is enhanced, implying that the 5.4 eV band is extrinsic and only the 3.95 eV band with pi character is intrinsic.  We also conclude that the holes in LiBr are mobile and migrate to impurities to recombine with electrons there, emitting the 5.4 eV luminescence.

TI HIGH-SENSITIVITY OF ELECTROREFLECTANCE TO STARK-LADDER TRANSITIONS IN A
   GAAS ALAS SUPERLATTICE
SO SOLID STATE COMMUNICATIONS
LA English
DT Article
ID PERIOD GAAS/ALAS SUPERLATTICE; ELECTRIC-FIELD; QUANTUM WELLS;
   LOCALIZATION
AB Using electroreflectance spectroscopy, we have succeeded for the first time to observe the Stark-ladder formation of the second (n = 2) quantization state in addition to that of the n = 1 state in a GaAs (6.4 nm)A1As (0.9 nm) superlattice with a p-i-n structure at 77K.  From the comparison between electroreflectance and photocurrent spectra, it is demonstrated that electroreflectance spectroscopy is much more sensitive for probing the Stark-ladder transition than photocurrent spectroscopy.  We discuss the high sensitivity of electroreflectance from the modulation mechanism.

TI SPIN REORIENTATIONS IN (ND1-XYX)2CO14B COMPOUNDS
SO JOURNAL OF MAGNETISM AND MAGNETIC MATERIALS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 25TH CONF OF THE YAMADA SCIENCE FOUNDATION : MAGNETIC PHASE TRANSITIONS
CY APR 13-16, 1990
CL OSAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
ID RARE-EARTH; R2CO14B
AB The magnetization measurement and the Co-59 NMR have been performed for (Nd(1-x)Y(x))2Co14B compounds.  The spin reorientation temperature decreases with increasing Y-concentration for 0 less-than-or-equal-to x less-than-or-equal-to 0.85.  The shape of the Co-59 NMR spectra changes drastically for 0.85 less-than-or-equal-to x less-than-or-equal-to 1.0.  These results suggest that the transition of the easy direction of magnetization appears near x = 0.9.
C1 NAGANO NATL COLL TECHNOL,NAGANO 380,JAPAN.

TI MAGNETIC-PROPERTIES OF SM2(CO1-XMNX)14B, SM2(CO1XFEX)14B,
   SM2(CO1-XNI)14B
SO JOURNAL OF MAGNETISM AND MAGNETIC MATERIALS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 25TH CONF OF THE YAMADA SCIENCE FOUNDATION : MAGNETIC PHASE TRANSITIONS
CY APR 13-16, 1990
CL OSAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
ID NMR
AB The Co-59 NMR and magnetic measurements in Sm2(Co(1-x)T(x))14B (T = Mn, Fe, Ni) have been carried out at 4.2 and 77 K, respectively.  The Co-59 hyperfine fields in Sm2(Co(1-x)T(x))14B increase for T = Fe, and decrease for T = Mn, Ni with increasing T-concentration.  These results show that the Co-59 hyperfine fields depend on nearest neighbor T atoms.

TI MAGNETIC-PROPERTIES OF Y(CO1-XNIX)2-HYDRIBES, Y(CO1-XALX)2-HYDRIBES
SO JOURNAL OF MAGNETISM AND MAGNETIC MATERIALS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 25TH CONF OF THE YAMADA SCIENCE FOUNDATION : MAGNETIC PHASE TRANSITIONS
CY APR 13-16, 1990
CL OSAKA, JAPAN
SP YAMADA SCI FDN
AB Magnetization measurements have been performed on the hydrides Y(Co(1-x)T(x))2H(y) (T = Ni, Al) at 4.2 K.  In all hydrides, ferromagnetism has been observed.  The occurrence of ferromagnetism in the hydrides may be ascribed to a lattice expansion (almost-equal-to 7%) by hydrogen absorption and an electron transfer.

TI NMR-STUDY OF HIGH-TC SUPERCONDUCTOR
SO JOURNAL OF MAGNETISM AND MAGNETIC MATERIALS
LA English
DT Article
ID NUCLEAR-QUADRUPOLE RESONANCE; KNIGHT-SHIFT; CU-63; CU
AB Cu-63 NQR, O-17 and Tl-205 NMR studies are reviewed for (La(1-x)Sr(x))2CuO4, YBa2Cu3O7 and Tl2Ba2CuO(6-y). As for the superconducting properties, the temperature dependence of the Knight shift as well as the nuclear spin lattice relaxation time possessing the common unconventional feature for all compounds are consistent with the presence of the larger energy gap in the CuO2 plane than the BCS prediction. The normal state in the superconducting compound is demonstrated to be predominated by the antiferromagnetic (AF) spin correlation, while for the non-superconducting sample, the AF spin correlation is reduced, suggesting the interrelation between the superconductivity and the AF spin correlation.
RP KITAOKA, Y (reprint author), OSAKA UNIV, FAC ENGN SCI, DEPT MAT PHYS, TOYONAKA, OSAKA 560, JAPAN.

AU NAGATA, S
   FUJIWARA, K
   NISHIMURA, H
AF NAGATA, S
   FUJIWARA, K
   NISHIMURA, H
TI DYNAMIC ASPECTS OF EXCITONS IN NAI
SO JOURNAL OF LUMINESCENCE
LA English
DT Article
ID SELF-TRAPPED EXCITON; ALKALI-HALIDE CRYSTALS; LUMINESCENCE; DIFFUSION;
   NACL
AB Observing the relations between the intensities and also between the decay curves of excitonic luminescence and impurity luminescence in NaI crystals as a function of temperature, we have studied the energy transfer from excitions to impurities.  The energy transfer is mainly caused by free excition motion at low temperature, and by hopping motion of self-trapped excitons at high temperature.  The activation energy of the hopping motion is estimated to be 70 meV.  The quenching process of the excitonic luminescence has also been studied.  Surface recombination of free and self-trapped excitions is occasionally the main process.  This process competes with collision processes of excitons with impurities, by which the exciton energy is transferred to the impurity.

   ELECTRICAL AND ELECTRONIC ENGINEERING
LA English
DT Article
ID ELEMENT
AB Benchmark problem 7 of the TEAM workshop consists of an asymmetrical conductor with a hole.  17 computer codes are applied, and 25 solutions are compared with each other and with experimental results for eddy current densities and flux densities.  Most of the codes were found to give satisfactory solutions.

TI RESULTS FOR BENCHMARK PROBLEM-10 (STEEL PLATES AROUND A COIL)
SO COMPEL-THE INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL FOR COMPUTATION AND MATHEMATICS IN
   ELECTRICAL AND ELECTRONIC ENGINEERING
LA English
DT Article
AB Benchmark problem 10 of the TEAM workshop consists of steel plates around a coil (non-linear transient eddy current problem). Some codes were found to give oscillatory solutions.

TI VISCOSITY MOLECULAR-WEIGHT RELATION OF THERMOTROPIC LIQUID-CRYSTALLINE
   COPOLYESTERS
SO KOBUNSHI RONBUNSHU
LA Japanese
DT Article
DE THERMOTROPIC LIQUID CRYSTALLINE POLYMERS; COPOLYESTERS; WEIGHT AVERAGE
   MOLECULAR WEIGHT; MARK-HOUWINK-SAKURADA RELATION; FLORY K-VALUE;
   CHARACTERISTIC RATIO
ID POLYMERS
AB A series of well known thermotropic liquid crystalline random copolyesters which were synthesized from poly(ethylene terephthalate) and 60 mol% p-hydroxybenzonic acid was characterized with respect to the weight average molecular weight MBAR(w) by sedimentation equilibrium of the dilute solution in 1,1,1,3,3,3,-hexafluoro-2-propanol as well as the intrinsic viscosity ([eta]) in a mixture of phenol/1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane (1:1 by weight).  The following Mark-Houwink-Sakurada relation was established:  [eta] = 1.30 x 10(-3)MBAR(w)0.67 at 30-degrees-C.  The Flory K value of 3.6 x 10(-3) was obtained by the method of Stockmayer-Fixman.  The characteristic ratio of the copolyesters was close to that of poly-(ethylene terephthalate), suggesting that the chain of the copolyesters is as flexible as that of poly(ethylene terephtalate) in the solution state.
C1 IDEMITSU PETROCHEM CO LTD,PERFORMANCE POLYMERS RES LAB,SODEGAURA,CHIBA 29902,JAPAN.
   KYOTO UNIV,MED POLYMERS & BIOMAT RES CTR,SAKYO KU,KYOTO 606,JAPAN.
   KYOTO UNIV,DEPT POLYMER CHEM,SAKYO KU,KYOTO 606,JAPAN.

AU KITAOKA, Y
   FUJIWARA, K

   ASAYAMA, K
AF KITAOKA, Y
   FUJIWARA, K
   ISHIDA, K
   OHSUGI, S
   ASAYAMA, K
TI SPIN CORRELATION AND SUPERCONDUCTIVITY IN HIGH-TC OXIDES
SO PROGRESS OF THEORETICAL PHYSICS SUPPLEMENT
LA English
DT Article
AB Cu-63 NQR and NMR and O-17 NMR studies are presented for La2-xSr(x)CuO4, YBa2Cu3O7 and Tl2Ba2CuO6+y.  In the superconducting state, the T-dependence of the Knight shift has shown that the superconducting energy gap is larger in the CuO2 (2-DELTA/k(B)T(c) = 4.4 - 4.9) than the BCS prediction, being consistent with an s-wave model.  In contrast, the T1 result below T(c) cannot be interpreted by a simple s-wave model.
   In the normal state, T1(-1) of Cu is strongly enhanced by antiferromagnetic (AF) spin correlation and its T-dependence is related to the T-dependence of the staggered susceptibility X(Q)(T) at the zone boundary.  The large enhancement of X(Q) is remarkable for the superconducting compound, which is considered to play a key-role for the anomalous normal and superconducting properties in high T(c) oxides.  The correlation between T(c) and AF spin correlation is discussed.
RP KITAOKA, Y (reprint author), OSAKA UNIV,FAC ENGN SCI,DEPT MAT PHYS,TOYONAKA,OSAKA 560,JAPAN.
CR ALLOUL H, 1989, PHYS REV LETT, V63, P1700, DOI 10.1103/PhysRevLett.63.1700
